results.title: Nanook of the North [Silent]
results.creator_credit: Robert Joseph Flaherty, Films Incorporated and Pathe Exchange
results.brief_description: Robert Flaherty was commissioned by the Revillon Fur Company to make an advertising film, and the result of his visit to the Hudson Bay territory of Canada was “Nanook of the North”. It is difficult to realise that Flaherty had to work entirely alone and without the advantages of panchromatic stock. His use of realist material to present not a story but rather a dramatic theme of man’s struggle with his environment opened up a new realm of film-making. It was the first documentary film in the modern sense. The film shows Nanook, the Eskimo hunter, preparing with his family for the summer, his meeting with the white trader, catching walruses, seals and foxes, building an igloo, training his children in the arts of hunting, breaking camp, and finally returning through a wild storm to safety and rest in an old igloo.

results.title: Names of sin
results.creator_credit: Rolf Forsberg, Karl Holtsnider, Franciscan Communications Centre and Teleketics
results.brief_description: A dramatization about a nine-year-old girl Missy who is persuaded by her peers to throw a stone at an old lady. She later discovers that the old lady is dying and a personal awareness of having done an unloving act weighs heavily upon her. Her mother’s loving response to her torment and instinctive gestures of consolation even as she lets Missy know the seriousness of her action, frees Missy and she finds her own special way to express her sorrow. The dramatic tension traces the dynamics of the sacrament of Penance, as Missy experiences sorrow, guilt and the peace that comes with forgiveness.

results.title: Namekas: music in Lake Chambri
results.brief_description: Deals principally with the spiritual references that music has for the Lake Chambri people, featuring the sacred talking flutes that are played and seen only by men. Shows also songs of ceremonial and everyday nature, and other instruments, including the “talking” slit drums, panpipes, and a most unusual instrument in the form of a sago beetle. Produced with assistance from Australian Film Commission, Australia Council, Dept. Foreign Affairs and PNG National Cultural Council.

results.title: Nameday
results.creator_credit: Eleni Arbus and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: This short drama, shot in grainy colour, explores the conflict between a father and daughter within a contemporary Greek-Australian family. Estranged from her family for some time, a young women decides spontaneously to attend her father’s nameday party. When he rejects her, she determines to finally uncover the whole truth about a dark family secret that has haunted her since childhood. Told in a non-linear style, the film weaves together fragments of symbolic imagery and sound to evoke the memories that cause the daughter to suspect her father of murder. Each image sheds light on the previous, as the mysterious connection between the past and the present at the centre of the story is gradually revealed.

results.title: Name Your Poison
results.brief_description: The Tibaldi brothers add a light-hearted touch to the problem of alcohol. It covers reasons for drinking - boredom, rebellion, adult role models, peer pressure and the media - and looks at how some young people have developed a responsible attitude. An excellent discussion starter for young people about the use and abuse of alcohol.

results.title: Name unknown
results.brief_description: Through several episodes involving a lovers’ lane, baby sitting and a pickup, warns boys and girls against becoming victims of sexual criminals by pointing out the necessity of being aware of and avoiding possible dangers.

results.title: Naked intent
results.creator_credit: Chris Begley and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: A loose door number on a hotel room leads to surprises all round when novelty stripper Ralph Little finds himself performing for a gang of jewel thieves, all the while being watched by police surveillance - courtesy of a stuffed koala with a hidden camera.

results.title: Nails = Les Clous = Die Nagel
results.creator_credit: Kurt Aeschbacher and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: An abstract statement on the problem of over population. A community of nails busily propagates, builds and spreads within a limited area. Eventually there is no more area for living and the nails rust and corrode. Music by Bruno Spoerri.
results.description: An abstract statement on the problem of over population. A community of nails busily propagates, builds and spreads within a limited area. Eventually there is no more area for living and the nails rust and corrode. Music by Bruno Spoerri.

results.title: Nahanni
results.brief_description: The legend of a lost gold mine and a river in the Northwest Territories that lures men to their doom. Albert Faille, an aging prospector from Fort Simpson, has set out time after time to find hidden gold. His route is through a wild, awesome land particularly suited to the mood of this Canadian odyssey.

results.title: Nah - he was in a big house before (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Dave McRae, Patricia Edgar and La Trobe University. Centre for the Study of Educational Communication and Media
results.brief_description: The experiences of a teacher in his first year of teaching in a country high school. Investigates the town, the people, and the activities of the township, and then looks at the school and the problems concerning teachers in the school, with particular reference to his own experience in his first year. Written and directed by Dave McRae.
